title: Implement a Trait
description:
Practice defining and implementing traits.

## Requirements

1. Define a trait `Describable` with:
   - `fn describe(&self) -> String`
   - A default implementation of `fn describe_short(&self) -> String` that returns first 20 chars of describe()

2. Implement `Describable` for `Book` struct with fields: title, author, pages

3. Implement `Describable` for `Movie` struct with fields: title, director, minutes

testCases.assertion: { let b = Book { title: "Test".into(), author: "Auth".into(), pages: 100 }; b.describe().contains("Test") }
{ let b = Book { title: "Test".into(), author: "Auth".into(), pages: 100 }; b.describe().contains("Auth") }
{ let b = Book { title: "Test".into(), author: "Auth".into(), pages: 100 }; b.describe().contains("100") }
{ let m = Movie { title: "Film".into(), director: "Dir".into(), minutes: 90 }; m.describe().contains("Dir") }
{ let b = Book { title: "Very Long Title Here".into(), author: "Author".into(), pages: 100 }; b.describe_short().len() <= 20 }

hints: The trait definition needs: fn describe(&self) -> String;
Book struct: title: String, author: String, pages: u32
Use format!() to create the description strings
impl Describable for Book { fn describe(&self) -> String { ... } }
